George Harrison’s spirituality was influenced by eastern religions that, unlike the western focus on individuality, preach a loss of self and ego. Indeed, achieving nirvana or enlightenment in Buddhist traditions involves letting go of everything you cling to.
Never glimpse the truth, then it’s far too late when they pass away

The people who hide behind a wall of illusion such as materialistic things, superficial beauty, money, etc. never glimpse the truth of the world and never understand the meaning of life. They understand the meaning of life when they die and by then it is far too late. As George Harrison wrote and composed this song he poured his beliefs of Hinduism/eastern religious teachings into the song.

George Harrison wrote this song and what’s peculiar about it is that there were no other Beatles involved with it’s conception. This is only the 2nd Beatles song to do that, the first being McCartney in “Yesterday”

The song features a group of unknown Indian musicians from “The Asian Music Circle” in Finchley, North London.

This song was heavily influenced by Harrison’s love of Classical Indian Music and Vedanta Philosophy.

Some instruments featured in the song that are rather uncommon in western music are:


Sitar
Tambura
Dilruba
Svarmandal
Tabla



This was Harrison’s second full blown Indian recording, the first being “Love You To”

We were talking about the space between us all

“Within You Without You” was composed by George Harrison following a deep conversation during a dinner party at the London home of long-time friend Klaus Voorman. Voorman designed the cover for “Revolver” and was awarded the Grammy Award for Best Album Cover, Graphic Arts.
And the people who gain the world and lose their soul

This is a paraphrase of a statement attributed to Jesus Christ, from The Book of St. Matthew 16:26:

For what profit is it to a man if he gains the whole world, and loses his own soul?

Bob Marley wrote an inspiring take on the line in Zion Train:

And to see you’re really only very small
 And life flows on within you and without you

There is some existential wordplay here:


Life flowing within and without simply means that the flow of energy that sustains life is all pervasive, the energy is everywhere.
Life flows “Within you” as a manifestation of the world “Without”; when you die, life will still flow on Without you.



This statement reflects George’s burgeoning Hindu beliefs.

The Hindu text “Svetasvatara Upanisad” states:

The atma [soul] is the size of 1/10,000th of a human hair.
